questions.text: What does a deep sulcus sign represent?
questions.solution:
• In supine patients, free pneumothorax usually collects within the anterior pleural space.
  • A visceral pleural line may be seen medially in some patients, mimicking pneumomediastinum.
  • A subpulmonic pneumothorax with a visible visceral pleural line may be seen at the lung base.
  • Less specific findings of pneumothorax in supine patients include the following:
  • The costophrenic angle may appear abnormally deep and lucent because of air in the anterolateral pleura space, the “deep sulcus sign”.
  • Increased lucency over the chest or upper abdomen
  • Visualization of the anterior costophrenic angle as an edge separate from the diaphragm but parallel to it (the “double-diaphragm sign”)
  • Increased sharpness of the hemidiaphragm (because it is outlined by air), despite lung disease
  • Increased sharpness of the cardiac border or mediastinum
  • Air in the minor fissure
  • A lumpy appearance at the cardiac apex due to alteration in the shape of the epicardial fat pad in the presence of pneumothorax.

Reference:Thoracic imaging-Pulmonary and cardiovascular radiology edition 3  pg 2142

questions.text: A patient presented with red coloured sputum. On doing a CXR, the following image was obtained. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Lobar consolidation with lobar expansion gives rise to the bulging fissure sign which is shown in the image above.
  • This is characteristic of Klebsiella pneumonia along with red coloured sputum. Red coloured sputum should not be confused with haemoptysis as the red colour in such cases is due to pigments.

Reference: Thoracic imaging-Pulmonary and cardiovascular radiology edition 3 pg 12

questions.text: A patient presented with weight loss and haemoptysis. On doing a CXR, the following image was obtained. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The given image shows a hilar opacity which is suggestive of mass lesion. Hilar enlargement visible on radiographs can reflect the primary tumor arising in a central location (usually, this results in a poorly marginated hilar mass that may be large) or metastases to hilar lymph nodes from a peripheral lung primary (usually a well-defined hilar mass). Hilar mass is common in SCC.
  • Enlargement of hilar lymph nodes in association with a central mass is characteristic of small cell carcinoma. Hilar enlargement is the first detectable radiographic finding in 10% to 15% of cases of lung cancer. Airway abnormalities (narrowing or obstruction) are common, but not invariably, seen in patients with a hilar mass or lymph node enlargement.

Reference: Thoracic imaging-Pulmonary and cardiovascular radiology edition 3 pg 450

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Pleural plaques are the most common manifestation of asbestos-related disease and can be identified with a very high degree of specificity with CT. Pleural plaques exhibit the so-called "incomplete border sign" on chest radiograph. The inner margin is often well-defined because it is tangential to the x-ray beam and the adjacent lung is a good contrast medium.
  • The tapering outer margin is indistinct as it is end face to the x-ray beam and the chest wall provides less tissue contrast. Calcified plaques are more obvious than non-calcified plaques to be identified.
  • Locations most commonly encountered include posterolateral, mediastinal, and diaphragmatic pleura. The appearance of plaques has been likened to that of a holly leaf, with thickened rolled and nodular edges.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no pg 2527

choices.text: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
A is true but R is false
Both A and R are false

questions.text:
Assertion: Air bronchogram sign is seen in consolidation.
Reason: Air within the trachea and bronchi is translucent.
questions.solution:
• In patients with consolidation, air-filled bronchi are often visible on plain radiographs or CT, appearing lucent compared with opacified lung parenchyma.
  • This finding is termed an air bronchogram. The bronchi usually appear normal in calibre, without evidence of displacement of distortion.

Reference: Thoracic imaging-Pulmonary and cardiovascular radiology edition 3 pg 23

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is the most common cyanotic congenital heart condition with many cases presenting after the new-born period.
  • It has been classically characterized by the combination of ventricular septal defect (VSD), right ventricular outflow tract obstruction (RVOTO), overriding aorta, and late right ventricular hypertrophy.
  • Chest radiographs may classically show a 'boot-shaped' heart with an upturned cardiac apex due to right ventricular hypertrophy and concave pulmonary arterial segment.

Reference: Mc-Graw Hill speciality Board review Radiology page 339

questions.text: A patient had a history of trauma to the chest and developed breathlessness. On doing a CXR the following image was obtained. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows an enlarged heart with appearance of leather bottle which is suggestive of pericardial effusion. In patients with trauma, it might suggest presence of hemopericardium due to trauma.

Reference: Reference: Mc-Graw Hill speciality Board review Radiology page 321

questions.text: A patient presented with inferior rib nothcing on CXR. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Inferior rib notching is seen in coarctation of aorta. It is also known as Roesler sign. Roesler sign is the name given to the inferior rib notching seen in coarctation of the aorta. Although by no means pathognomonic, the sign is fairly specific.
  • Although many other causes of inferior rib notching have been recorded most of them are very rare. Strictly-speaking it is only called Roesler sign when the etiology of the inferior rib notching is coarctation.

Reference: Bell, D. Roesler sign. Reference article, Radiopaedia.org. https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-87424

questions.text: Presence of pulmonary plethora is a patient with congenital heart disease is suggestive of?
questions.solution:
• Pulmonary plethora is a term used to describe the appearances of increased pulmonary perfusion on chest radiographs. Usually a left-to-right shunt of 2:1 is required for pulmonary plethora to occur.
  • Features of pulmonary plethora:
  • prominent pulmonary vasculature
    • pulmonary vessels are dilated and tortuous extending farther into the peripheral one-thirds of the lungs
    • diameter of a pulmonary artery is greater than the accompanying bronchus
  • increased size and number of hilar pulmonary arteries
    • >3-5 end-on should be seen
    • diameter of the right descending pulmonary artery is bigger than the diameter of the trachea
  • cardiomegaly may be present

Reference: Knipe, H., Qureshi, P. Pulmonary plethora. Reference article, Radiopaedia.org. https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-41136

questions.text: Cardiac MRI is used for?
questions.solution:
Cardiac MRI consists of using MRI to study heart anatomy, physiology, and pathology. It is used for structural assessment, functional assessment and pathologies like MI, tumors etc.

Reference: Delgado, J., Marghany, B. Cardiac MRI. Reference article, Radiopaedia.org. https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-41244

questions.text: Which type of haemorrhage is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
• An EDH is a collection of blood between the calvaria and outer (periosteal) layer of the dura.
  • EDHs are biconvex in shape. Adherence of the periosteal dura to the inner calvaria explains this typical configuration.
  • As EDHs expand, they strip the dura away from the inner table of the skull, forming the classic lens-shaped hematoma.
  • Because the dura is especially tightly attached to sutures, EDHs in adults rarely cross suture lines (10% of EDHs in children do cross sutures, especially if a fracture traverses the suture or sutural diastasis is present).

Reference: Osborn Brain edition 2 pg 21

questions.text: What is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
• IDH-wild-type glioblastoma (GBM) is the most common and most malignant of all astrocytoma.
  • They preferentially involve the subcortical and deep periventricular white matter, easily spreading across compact tracts such as the corpus callosum and corticospinal tracts. Symmetric involvement of the corpus callosum is common, the so-called "butterfly glioma" pattern GBMs are WHO grade IV neoplasms.
  • MR Spectroscopy usually shows elevated choline and decreased NAA.

Reference: Osborn Brain edition 2 pg 536

questions.text: A patient presented with fever and seizures. On doing an MRI the following image was obtained. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Neuro-tuberculosis is secondary to hematogenous spread from extracranial infection, most frequently in the lungs.
  • CNS TB begins with the development of small TB ("Rich") foci in the subpial or subependymal surfaces of the brain and spinal cord. Rupture of a Rich focus into the subarachnoid space causes meningitis, vasculitis, and occasionally encephalitis.
  • The most common parenchymal lesion in CNS TB is tuberculoma. Mild to moderate round or lobulated ring-like enhancement around a non-enhancing center is the most typical pattern.
  • Other findings in CNS TB are: meningitis, abscess and cerebritis.

Reference: Osborn Brain edition 2 pg 377

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy (X-ALD) is also known as childhood cerebral X-ALD (CCALD). It was historically known as "bronze" Schilder disease and "melanodermic type leukodystrophy" before its adrenal involvement was recognized. A posterior-predominant pattern is seen in 80% of patients with X-ALD.
  • The earliest spin magnitude finding is T2/FLAIR hyperintensity in the middle of the corpus callosum splenium. As the disease progresses, hyperintensity spreads from posterior to anterior and from the center to the periphery.
  • The peri-trigonal WM, corticospinal tracts, fornix, commissural fibers, plus the visual and auditory pathways can all eventually become involved. The leading edge of demyelination appears hyperintense on T1WI but does not enhance.
  • The intermediate zone of active inflammatory demyelination typically enhances T1 C+. Thus, always include T1 C+ when imaging suspected leukodystrophy

Reference: Osborn Brain edition 2 pg 966

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution:
• Open ring enhancement is seen in demyelinating disease like MS.
  • Closed ring enhancement is suggestive of granulomatous etiology like TB.
  • Ring enhancing with central dot is seen in NCC.

Reference: Osborn Brain edition 2 pg 377, 390, 449.

questions.text: Greatest risk to foetus for malformations due to radiation exposure is during ______ trimester.
questions.solution:
• The effect of radiation exposure during pregnancy also depends on the gestational age of the foetus. The embryo/foetus is most susceptible to radiation during organogenesis (2 to 7 weeks gestational age) and in the first trimester.
  • The foetus is more resistant to the radiation during the second and third trimester. Dose between 0.05 to 0.5 Gy is generally considered safe for the foetus during the second and third trimester while it is considered potentially harmful during the 1st-trimester foetus.
  • Even though the foetus is more resistant to the radiation during the second and third trimester, a high dose of radiation (greater than 0.5 Gy or 50 rad) may result in adverse effects including miscarriage, growth reduction, IQ reduction, and severe mental retardation. Therefore, clinicians and radiologists should counsel the pregnant patient regardless of the gestational age.

Reference: Yoon I, Slesinger TL. Radiation Exposure In Pregnancy. [Updated 2022 May 8]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2022 Jan.

questions.text: What is used as an anode in mammography tube?
questions.solution:
• If a bombarding electron penetrates the K-shell and approaches close to the nucleus it is deflected. It approaches fast and leaves less quickly, losing some or all of its energy.
  • The lost energy is carried away as a single photon of X-rays or bremsstrahlung (literally, 'braking radiation'). Except in mammography, 80% or more of the X-rays emitted by a diagnostic X-ray tube are bremsstrahlung. The target (anode) used in mammography is molybdenum.

Reference: Farr's physics for medical imaging page no 7

questions.text: What is used in the production of ultrasound waves?
questions.solution:
• Ultrasound transducers use piezoelectricity. Piezoelectric materials have the unique ability to respond to the action of an electric field by changing shape. They also have the property of generating electric potentials when compressed.
  • Changing the polarity of a voltage applied to the transducer changes the thickness of the transducer, which expands and contracts as the polarity changes.
  • This results in the generation of mechanical pressure waves that can be transmitted into the body. The piezoelectric effect also results in the generation of small potentials across the transducer when the transducer is struck by returning echoes.

Reference: Christensen's Physics of diagnostic radiology page 327

questions.text: A patient presented with an inability to abduct the thumb following an injury with a sharp instrument. A tendon injury was suspected. Which type of probe is most suitable for examination of the suspected tendons?
questions.solution:
Linear probe is used for visualising the superficial structures like bowel and tendons. It is a high frequency probe and therefore provides with good resolution however there is reduced penetration.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 503

questions.text: What is the preferred investigation in a patient with 4 months amenorrhea and presenting with ureteric stone?
questions.solution:
• The effect of radiation exposure during pregnancy also depends on the gestational age of the foetus. The embryo/foetus is most susceptible to radiation during organogenesis (2 to 7 weeks gestational age) and in the first trimester. The foetus is more resistant to the radiation during the second and third trimester.
  • Dose between 0.05 to 0.5 Gy is generally considered safe for the foetus during the second and third trimester while it is considered potentially harmful during the 1st-trimester foetus.
  • Even though the foetus is more resistant to the radiation during the second and third trimester, a high dose of radiation (greater than 0.5 Gy or 50 rad) may result in adverse effects including miscarriage, growth reduction, IQ reduction, and severe mental retardation. USG does not utilize ionizing radiation and used sound waves and therefore is safe during pregnancy. Thus, such patients, USG can be used for making the diagnosis.

Reference: Yoon I, Slesinger TL. Radiation Exposure In Pregnancy. [Updated 2022 May 8]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2022 Jan.

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution: Reference: Greenway, K., Bell, D. Hounsfield unit. Reference article, Radiopaedia.org. https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-38181

questions.text: What is shown in the image below (Long arrow) ?
questions.solution:
The given image is a CECT of the pelvis. It is a sagittal reformatted image showing uterus and urinary bladder. The structure pointed in the image is uterus.

Reference: The Requisite Genitourinary Imaging, third edition page no 248

questions.text: Which image is shown in the image below?
questions.solution: Reference: MRI MADE EASY page 14

questions.text: Helium in MRI machine is used for?
questions.solution:
The coil made of superconducting material in MRI machine is cooled to 4K (-269 degree Celsius) by cryogens like liquid helium, which surrounds the coil all around. Because of smaller heat leaks into the system, helium steadily boils off.

Reference: MRI made easy page no 26

questions.text: What is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
• The given image shows the femoral head epiphysis on left side outside the acetabular fossa and in the upper outer quadrant based on Perkin's line and Hilgenriner's line.
  • This is highly suggestive of developmental dysplasia of hip.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 1404

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Osteosarcomas are malignant bone-forming tumors.

They are the second most common primary bone tumor after multiple myeloma,

Typical appearances of conventional high-grade osteosarcoma include:

  • Medullary and cortical bone destruction
  • Wide zone of transition, permeative or moth-eaten appearance
  • Aggressive periosteal reaction
    • sunburst type
    • Codman triangle
    • lamellated (onion skin) reaction: less frequently seen
  • Soft-tissue mass
  • Tumor matrix ossification/calcification
    • variable: reflects a combination of the amount of tumor bone production, calcified matrix, and osteoid
    • ill-defined "fluffy" or "cloud-like" compared to the rings and arcs of chondroid lesions
  • Lung and nodal metastases may be ossified

Reference:AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 966

questions.text: What is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
• Paget disease of the bone is a common, chronic bone disorder characterized by excessive abnormal bone remodelling. The classically described radiological appearances are expanded bone with a coarsened trabecular pattern. The pelvis, spine, skull, and proximal long bones are most frequently affected.
  • Plain radiographic features will depend upon the phase of the disease.
  • The early phase features osteolytic (lucent) regions which are later followed by coarsened trabeculae and bony enlargement. Sclerotic changes occur much later in the disease process. Additional destructive features may become apparent if malignant transformation occurs.
  • Skull
  • osteoporosis circumscripta: large, well-defined lytic lesions involving the inner aspect of the outer table of the skull (stage one) with a preserved inner table.
  • cotton wool appearance: mixed lytic and sclerotic lesions of the skull.
  • diploic widening: both inner and outer calvarial tables are involved, with the former usually more extensively affected
  • Tam o' Shanter sign: platybasia and basilar invagination with the appearance of the skull falling over the facial bones, like a Tam o' Shanter hat
  • Spine
  • picture frame sign: Paget disease of the spine frequently manifests with cortical thickening and sclerosis encasing the vertebral margins, which gives rise to this appearance on radiographs in mixed-phase disease
  • squaring of vertebrae: on lateral radiographs, flattening of the normal concavity of the anterior margin of the vertebral body also adds to the rectangular appearance
  • vertical trabecular thickening: coarser than the more delicate pattern seen in intraosseous hemangiomas with which it may be confused
  • Pelvis
  • cortical thickening and sclerosis of the iliopectineal and ischiopubic lines results in the pelvic brim sign and leads to obliteration of Kohler's teardrop
  • acetabular protrusion
  • enlargement of the pubic rami and ischium

These findings are often asymmetric, and for some reason, are more commonly seen on the right side.

Long bones

  • blade of grass or candle flame sign: begins as a subchondral area of lucency with advancing tip of V-shaped osteolysis, extending towards the diaphysis
    • in rare cases, the disease is isolated to the diaphysis, most commonly in the tibia, rather than subchondral bone, which can cause diagnostic confusion
  • lateral curvature (bowing) of the femur
  • anterior curvature of the tibia

Reference:AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2743

questions.text: Cobb's angle is used in?
questions.solution:
The Cobb angle is the most widely used measurement to quantify the magnitude of spinal deformities, especially in the case of scoliosis, on plain radiographs. Scoliosis is defined as a lateral spinal curvature with a Cobb angle of >10°.

Reference:AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2850

questions.text: Rhizomelia and trident hand are features of ?
questions.solution:
• Achondroplasia is a congenital genetic disorder resulting in rhizomelic dwarfism and is the most common skeletal dysplasia.
  • The disease results from a mutation in the fibroblast growth factor gene 3 (FGFR3) located on chromosome 4p16.3 which causes abnormal cartilage formation.
  • Few of the radiographic features of achondroplasia are as follows:
  • Pelvis
  • small squared (tombstone or mickey mouse ear) iliac wings
  • small trident acetabulum
  • champagne glass type pelvic inlet
  • Limbs
  • the femora and humeri are particularly shortened (rhizomelic shortening)
  • trident hand
  • chevron sign 16,17
  • The metacarpal and metatarsal bones, and in some cases the proximal phalanges, are short and of similar length

Reference:AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 1338

questions.text: Which of the following image shows a waveform of umbilical artery?
questions.solution:
• The normal waveform of umbilical artery in the third trimester is low resistance, with continuous forward flow throughout diastole.
  • Diastolic flow increases as pregnancy progresses, so the S/D ratio decreases with advancing gestational age. At 20 weeks, the 50th percentile for the S/D ratio is 4. At 30 weeks, the 50th percentile is 2.83; and at 40 weeks, the 50th percentile is 2.18.
  • In current clinical practice, the S/D ratio and the presence of absent or reversed end-diastolic flow are used to manage foetal growth restriction and to stage the twin-twin transfusion syndrome.


Reference: A Radiologist's Guide to the Performance and Interpretation of Obstetric Doppler US

Anne M. Kennedy and Paula J. Woodward

Radio Graphics 2019 39:3, 893-910

questions.text: Nuchal Translucency is used for?
questions.solution:
This scan is done for detection of:

  • Chromosomal markers & major structural anomalies in aneuploidies.
    Nuchal Translucency: Translucency between the skin and soft tissues posterior to the cervical spine.
  • Measuring Nuchal translucency
  • When CRL is between 36 and 80mm. (10.3 - 13.6wks). In true sagittal section.
  • With maximum magnification - 75% of the screen should be covered. (caliper 0.1mm). Neutral position- neither extension, nor flexion of the head. Mean of three values

Reference: Ultrasound in obstetrics and gynecology by Dr. P. K. shah, Dr. Mandakini megh, Dr. Nandita palshetkar page 52

questions.text: Which of the following image shows a uni-cornuate uterus?
questions.solution: Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no. 297

questions.text: Which of the following is not used in TIRADS scoring?
questions.solution: Reference:Jha, P., Weerakkody, Y. Thyroid imaging reporting and data system (TI-RADS). Reference article, Radiopaedia.org. https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-21448

questions.text: What is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The given image shows an axial scan through the head and neck region which shows parotid gland on both sides on the posterior aspect of ramus of mandible.

Reference:AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 3768

questions.text: Ameloblastoma usually affects which of the following bone?
questions.solution:
• Ameloblastomas are locally aggressive benign tumours that arise from the mandible, or, less commonly, from the maxilla. They usually present as a slowly but continuously growing hard painless lesion near the angle of the mandible in the 3rd to 5th decades of life, which can be severely disfiguring if left untreated. Multi-cystic ameloblastomas account for 80-90% of cases which are classically expansile 'soap-bubble' lesions, with well-demarcated borders and no matrix calcification. Resorption of adjacent teeth and 'root blunting' is often a feature. When larger it may also erode through the cortex into adjacent soft tissues.
  • Unicystic ameloblastomas are well-demarcated unilocular lesions that are often pericoronal in position. These are commonly found in the posterior mandible, particularly at the molars. They are indistinguishable from other unilocular pericoronal lesions, such as dentigerous cysts, ameloblastic fibromas and odontogenic keratocysts on CT.

Reference:Gaillard, F., Worsley, C. Ameloblastoma. Reference article, Radiopaedia.org. https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-877

questions.text: What is shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The given image is of gall bladder. It shows few hyperechoic structures within it which are casting posterior acoustic shadow. This is highly suggestive of gall bladder calculi.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 514

questions.text: A lesion was seen in liver which appeared hyperechoic on USG. On doing a triple phase CECT, it showed peripheral puddling with gradual filling and washout on delayed images. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Hepatic haemangiomas or hepatic venous malformations are the most common benign vascular liver lesions.
  • They are frequently diagnosed as an incidental finding on imaging, and most patients are asymptomatic.
  • Most haemangiomas are relatively well-defined. The dynamic enhancement pattern is related to the size of its vascular space.
  • Features of typical lesions include:
  • non-contrast: often hypoattenuating relative to liver parenchyma
    late arterial phase: typically show discontinuous, nodular, peripheral enhancement (small lesions may show uniform enhancement)
  • portal venous phase: progressive peripheral enhancement with more centripetal fill-in
  • delayed phase: further irregular fill-in and therefore iso- or hyper-attenuating to liver parenchyma

Reference:AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page 1905

questions.text: What is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a tubular blind ending structure arising from the caecum. This is suggestive of appendix.

Reference:AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 1151

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of RIF pain?
questions.solution:
Right iliac fossa mass is a common clinical presentation and has a range of differentials that need to be excluded.

Differential diagnosis:

  • appendicular mass
  • ileocecal tuberculosis (hyperplastic type)
  • intussusception
  • carcinoma cecum
  • tubo-ovarian mass, e.g., abscess
  • undescended testis
  • transplanted kidney
  • ectopic kidney

Reference:Goel, A., Bell, D. Right iliac fossa mass (differential). Reference article, Radiopaedia.org. https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-31457

questions.text: Modified CTSI is used in?
questions.solution:
The following is used for CTSI of pancreatitis

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page 1220

choices.text: Alcoholic liver disease with suspicious nodule

questions.text: LI-RADS is not used in?
questions.solution:
• Liver Imaging Reporting and Data System (LI-RADS) is both a set of standardized terminology and a classification system for imaging findings in liver lesions. The LI-RADS score for a liver lesion is an indication of its relative risk for hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).
  • The classification system is meant to be used in livers that have risk factors for HCC (e.g. cirrhotic livers, chronic HBV without cirrhosis). LI-RADS is not meant to be used in patients <18 years old, those with cirrhosis due to congenital hepatic fibrosis, and those with cirrhosis due to vascular disorders (e.g. Budd-Chiari syndrome).

Reference: Morgan, M., Worsley, C. LI-RADS. Reference article, Radiopaedia.org. https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-32465

questions.text: Gamma gandy bodies appear _____ on USG.
questions.solution:
• Gamma gandy bodies appear hyperechoic on USG and are seen in spleen in patients with cirrhosis. Gamma-Gandy bodies are small multiple siderotic lesions in the spleen They contain hemosiderin, calcium, and fibrous tissue.
  • These siderotic nodules are related to portal vein or splenic vein thrombosis, acquired hemochromatosis, haemolytic anaemia, leukaemia or lymphoma and they represent organized foci of haemorrhage.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page 1856

questions.text: Identify the organ showed in the image.
questions.solution:
The given image is an axial section of the abdomen. The marked structure is the pancreas.

Reference:AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page 440

questions.text: Central scar is seen in?
questions.solution:
• Oncocytomas are the most common benign solid non-fat containing renal mass. Central scar is seen in oncocytomas.
  • This occurs due to spoke wheel pattern of feeding artery and central areas of fibrous scarring giving rise to a central scar like appearance.

Reference:AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology pg 141

questions.text: What is used to estimate GFR?
questions.solution:
• Selection of the renal radiopharmaceutical is dependent on the parameter one wishes to assess.
  • Twenty percent of total renal function is the result of glomerular filtration; the remaining 80% is the result of tubular secretion.
  • 99mTc diethylenetriamine penta-acetic acid (99mTc DTPA) is almost entirely filtered through the glomerulus, and therefore is glomerular filtration rate (GFR).
  • 99mTc DTPA can demonstrate renal perfusion (radionuclide angiogram), renal parenchymal abnormalities, and assesses the renal collecting system and bladder for obstruction.

Reference:Mc-Graw Hill speciality Board review Radiology page 749

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The given image shows flower vase appearance of IVP.
  • Flower vase appearance of IVP occurs as the lower poles of the kidney fuses with each other the medulla is turned medially and appear together thus giving the flower of vase appearance.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 58

questions.text: What is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
• Given X-ray shows a well-defined radio-opacity in pelvis in midline. The most probable diagnosis is urinary bladder calculus from the given image.

Reference:AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 200

questions.text: Which of the following stone is not seen on XRay?
questions.solution:
Uric acid, Triamterene, Indinavir and Xanthine stones are radiolucent and therefore not seen in Xray KUB.

Reference:AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 53

questions.text: Heat damaged RBC is used in?
questions.solution:
• Heat-damaged red blood cells are cleared by functioning splenic tissue. Therefore radionuclide (Tc-99m pertechnetate) labelled heat damaged RBC can also be used for splenic imaging.
  • Heat damage is accomplished generally by heating RBCs in a water-bath at 49°C to 50°C for 20 minutes.
  • Imaging is begun 30 minutes to 2 hours after reinjection of the heat damaged RBCs.
  • If ectopic splenic tissue is suspected, images of the entire abdomen (or chest depending on the situation, i.e., prior trauma) are obtained.

Reference:Mc-Graw Hill speciality Board review Radiology page 746

choices.text: Keeping the radioactive source on the skin
Keeping the radioactive source in the lumen
Inserting the radioactive source into the tissue

questions.text: Interstitial brachytherapy consists of ?
questions.solution:
• Interstitial brachytherapy consists of inserting radioactive sources into tissue. Most modern methods tend to use Iridium-192 wire.
  • Prostate cancer treatment with Iodine-125 seeds is also classified as interstitial brachytherapy.

Reference: Mehta, SR & Suhag, Virender & Semwal, Manoj & Sharma, Neelam. (2010). Radiotherapy: Basic Concepts and Recent Advances. Medical Journal Armed Forces India. 66. 158-162. 10.1016/S0377-1237(10)80132-7 page 6
